Article.ArticleTitle: Nitrous oxide emissions decrease with plant diversity but increase with grassland primary productivity.

AbstractText: Nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O), a main greenhouse gas that contributes to ozone layer depletion, is released from soils. Even when it has been argued that agriculture is the main cause of its increase in the atmosphere, natural ecosystems are also an important source of N<sub>2</sub>O. However, the impacts of human activities on N<sub>2</sub>O emissions through biodiversity loss or primary productivity changes in natural ecosystems have rarely been assessed. Here, we analyzed the effects of vegetation attributes such as plant diversity and production, as drivers of N<sub>2</sub>O emission rates, in addition to environmental factors. We measured N<sub>2</sub>O emissions monthly during 1 year in 12 sites covering a large portion of the Rio de la Plata grasslands, Argentina, and related these emissions with climate, soil and vegetation attributes. We performed spatial and temporal models of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions separately, to evaluate which drivers control N<sub>2</sub>O in space and over time independently. Our results showed that in the spatial model, N<sub>2</sub>O emissions decreased with increments in plant species richness, with concomitant reductions in soil [Formula: see text] whereas N<sub>2</sub>O emissions increased with primary productivity. By contrast, in the temporal model, monthly precipitation and monthly temperature were the main drivers of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions, with positive correlations, showing important differences with the spatial model. Overall, our results show that biological drivers may exert substantial control of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions at large spatial scales, together with climate and soil variables. Our results suggest that biodiversity conservation of natural grasslands may reduce regional greenhouse gas emissions, besides maintaining other important ecosystem services.
